10.62.text: In July 2014, IWM London staged 'Truth and Memory: British Art of the First World War',

16.40.text: the first major retrospective of art created in response to the war for almost a century.

23.36.text: 'Truth and Memory' forms an integral part of the IWM's First World War

26.62.text: centenary programme. It also coincided with the relaunch

30.40.text: of the redeveloped IWM London site.

37.86.text: I'm Richard Slocombe, Senior Curator of Art and the curator of 'Truth and Memory'.

42.62.text: The exhibition occupied our two permanent galleries at IWM London.

48.52.text: The exhibition comprised almost 200 works of art,

51.30.text: that was painting, prints, drawings and sculptures,

54.10.text: and these mainly came from our renowned art collection,

57.64.text: and these are works that originated under the seminal official war art schemes

61.16.text: that Britain ran during the First World War.

64.56.text: 'Truth and Memory' sought to show how British artists

67.24.text: of all ages, all traditions and all backgrounds strived to represent

70.70.text: the unprecedented era-defining events of the First World War,

74.72.text: which ultimately helped shaped the nation's perception of the conflict

80.40.text: The exhibition presents a new interpretation of the British First World War art,

84.74.text: placing it firmly within the context of the times,

87.46.text: taking into account the critical and popular responses

95.02.text: The second half of the exhibition showed how British art

97.56.text: met the challenge of commemorating the First World War

100.10.text: and how this helped form the collective memory of the war as we know it today.

105.16.text: In doing so, it addressed why some pictures have seemed

108.12.text: to transcend definitions of art and come to epitomise

111.04.text: the slaughter and sacrifice of the First World War.

115.58.text: While we were in the early stages of planning 'Truth and Memory',

118.58.text: we were approached by York Museums Trust

120.86.text: regarding the possible collaboration as part of the

123.34.text: First World War centenary partnership, of which IWM leads.

128.26.text: (LORNA HOGGER) The catalyst for collaboration, aside from the centenary

131.12.text: itself,  was partly York Museums Trust's redevelopment

134.42.text: of York Art Gallery including the expansion of some of the first floor galleries.

138.14.text: York Art Gallery has a fantastic World War One painting

141.28.text: by Richard Jack, 'Return to the Front', so we approached

144.68.text: Imperial War Museum about doing an exhibition including that painting,

148.40.text: and a number of key works from their collection as well.

154.38.text: (SLOCOMBE) Right, well, welcome to the IWM art store Lorna.

159.16.text: As you can see, we have almost 2,000 paintings in here.

170.52.text: Well Lorna, this is 'Paths of Glory' by CRW Nevinson,

174.34.text: and, prior to the First World War, Nevinson fell under the spell

177.42.text: of the Italian Futurist movement, a movement that was committed

180.70.text: to all things modern, fast and violent.

184.66.text: [HOGGER] And it's a very shocking image actually,

186.66.text: and I understand that the War Office tried to censor it?

189.38.text: Yes, I mean, they succeeded in censoring it.

191.88.text: It was painted in 1917, just after the Passchendaele offensive -

195.70.text: a very costly offensive for the Allies - and, at the time, the mood in the country

198.76.text: was very low, and it was felt that a painting of this sort

202.80.text: was bad for morale essentially, it showed the failures of this offensive basically.

207.88.text: A censor, a chap called Major Lee, placed an injunction on it,

212.02.text: essentially banned it from public display,

214.72.text: because Nevinson, he was ever hopeful that that ban

218.02.text: would be lifted, and right up to the eleventh hour

220.94.text: when he was intending to show it and, when that ban wasn't lifted,

224.14.text: instead of removing it from display he left it in the show and, instead,

228.68.text: pasted a strip of gum strip across the painting

233.86.text: This was an act that got him into a fair bit of trouble actually.

236.98.text: Not only had he exhibited a banned painting,

240.36.text: he'd also used the word 'censored', which itself was censored.

244.68.text: He was delighted to report back to his superiors

247.34.text: that the controversy that had surrounded the displaying of this painting

251.44.text: had generated record-breaking crowds coming to see his show.

259.46.text: [HOGGER] So what are we going to look at next?

261.16.text: [SLOCOMBE] Well, it's another very large painting

263.26.text: and perhaps one of the finest paintings we have from the First World War

268.14.text: and this is Paul Nash's 'The Menin Road'.

272.38.text: [HOGGER] So Paul Nash was in the Hampshire regiment

274.44.text: and he went off to the Front but actually had a kind of

277.28.text: fortuitous accident and got sent home at a good point for him.

280.54.text: [SLOCOMBE] He certainly did, yes. He arrived at the Front in May 1917

284.62.text: and he was initially very excited about being at the Front.

287.74.text: He was trying to get a better view of a bombardment occurring at night

291.78.text: and climbed up to the parapet of the trench

294.50.text: and then promptly fell into the trench and broke a rib.

297.48.text: That bombardment was basically a precursor to the Messines offensive

302.26.text: which occurred while Nash was actually recuperating

305.60.text: and, of course, a lot of his regiment were killed in that campaign.

309.84.text: So he was very fortuitous  to have escaped that.

313.46.text: And, of course, in that recuperation period

316.58.text: he put on a show of his war drawings

319.70.text: which facilitated his own commissions as an official war artist.

324.54.text: And that was when his style and his viewpoint, his outlook

327.74.text: on the war kind of changed after that.

329.62.text: Very much so, I mean, he returned to his former positions in November 1917 -

336.62.text: this is after the Messines offensive - and found the whole area completely decimated.

340.76.text: He'd lost his colleagues, and... it was one of these sort of defining moments

344.76.text: where he actually realised what this war was about.

348.84.text: He always had this almost sort of spiritual, mystical regard for nature, particularly trees.

355.10.text: He saw this sort of violation of nature almost as a sort of wider metaphor

359.96.text: for the wider destruction of the war essentially.

364.24.text: This became a sort of central theme of his work

367.30.text: and, in doing so, he revitalised the English landscape tradition

371.54.text: and made it a very sort of expressive genre.

374.68.text: It's something you can see in this painting, 'The Menin Road' here,

377.92.text: with this sort of breaking storm of light,

381.06.text: you really get a sense of a world in chaos, in maelstrom here,

386.76.text: gripped by this modern, industrialised war.

397.58.text: [SLOCOMBE] Well Lorna, this is the Singer Sargent Gallery,

400.48.text: and this is William Orpen's 'To the Unknown Soldier in France'.

405.98.text: So William Orpen was a leading portrait artist,

408.84.text: and this was a really important commission for him.

410.98.text: [SLOCOMBE] Yes it was. It came at the behest of the Prime Minister, David Lloyd George.

415.26.text: What he was after was a permanent and suitable memento

418.86.text: to commemorate the Paris peace treaty, the Treaty of Versailles...

422.68.text: that would bring an end to the war and introduce the peacetime settlement, so...

428.08.text: Orpen already had this reputation as the sort of portrait painter

431.42.text: of the Edwardian great and good.

433.24.text: So he was seen as an ideal choice to produce group portraits

436.68.text: of the victorious Allied leaders overseeing this settlement.

442.22.text: [SLOCOMBE] This is one of three paintings he produced

445.24.text: but what they hadn't reckoned upon was the effect

447.74.text: that the war had had on Orpen essentially.

449.94.text: He'd gone out there as a war artist and seen what the war had done,

455.14.text: how it had affected France, how it had affected soldiers,

458.86.text: how it had affected the French civilians - it had very much disturbed him,

464.22.text: and the longer he was at the Paris conference,

466.80.text: the more disgusted he was at the sort of machinations of the politicians.

471.80.text: This painting... it was originally intended as a group portrait of the Allied generals

477.14.text: and leaders about to enter the Hall of Mirrors here, but he stopped doing that

481.56.text: and, instead, produce what was this very sort of heart-felt tribute to the British soldier.

488.92.text: What you can’t see now: he had two kind of guards of honor here,

493.66.text: which were these two very sort of emaciated British soldiers

497.06.text: and then above them there's... two cherubs carrying a sort of garland there,

503.66.text: a very sort of allegorical representation,

505.98.text: and this was his sort of heart-felt tribute to the British Tommy.

510.38.text: And it was a very popular picture with the British public.

514.26.text: It was shown in 1923 at the Royal Academy and voted the 'Picture of the Year'.

518.48.text: It was only in 1928 when Orpen decided to paint over the guards of honor and the cherubs

523.96.text: that it was actually accepted into the collection...

526.14.text: [HOGGER] Right, so it was only many years later he came back to it and changed it...

529.30.text: [HOGGER] ...and was that the pressure, do you think...?

530.98.text: [SLOCOMBE] Yeah... I think Orpen had just sort of come to terms with it

534.20.text: and decided to just go along with the museum's wishes... and decided to paint over it,

539.58.text: but... he only painted over very thinly, and you can just make out some of the details...

548.10.text: [SLOCOMBE] You can make out, particularly on this one,  you can make out the face there...

551.34.text: [HOGGER] So he didn't paint over it with conviction?

553.48.text: [SLOCOMBE] No, he just sort of... blocked them out essentially.

557.84.text: [SLOCOMBE] OK Lorna, this is another one of our very special paintings -

560.52.text: this is Stanley Spencer's 'Travoys Arriving with the Wounded'.

565.68.text: [LORNA] So can you tell us a little bit about what's going on in this painting?

568.66.text: [SLOCOMBE] Certainly. Spencer was a medical orderly in the Salonika campaign

572.62.text: in the Balkans in the First World War - quite different from other representations in the exhibition...

577.76.text: it's not a Western Front scene. The scene that he experienced himself during 1916

583.92.text: when the British attacked the Bulgarian position.

587.40.text: The attack occurred at night... and this is a scene of the wounded arriving back at a field hospital

594.42.text: and you see surgery sort of taking part over in the top corner there...

601.02.text: Spencer... very sort of idiosyncratic, religious views

604.60.text: he's taken that theme on into this painting here where you see the actual wounded

610.68.text: sort of arriving in the darkness, and then the brilliant light of the operating theatre here

617.22.text: so it's a sort of metaphorical coming from the darkness

620.34.text: the chaos of war to the light and redemption of the field hospital there.

631.64.text: [SLOCOMBE] Well this is a great opportunity to re-visit 'Truth and Memory'

634.44.text: and to take it out of London and to show it to a new audience.

637.26.text: It also gives us the opportunity to show more of our larger works

640.40.text: within the larger spaces at York Art Gallery

643.88.text: and it'll certainly give an impression of how some of the larger works would have looked

649.12.text: in that proposed Hall of Remembrance.

651.62.text: It certainly will be the first occasion for almost 100 years since 1919

656.42.text: that we've been able to bring so many of our larger First World War paintings together.
